awd_titl_txt: Multi-Physics of Elastomer Aging: Macrostructure Mechanical Properties based on Morphological Chemical Degenerations
awd_abstract_narration:
Elastomers, often commonly referred to as rubbers, have a wide range of applications as bearings, sealants, tires, and anti-vibration mountings. Under such operation, elastomers are exposed to oxygen and elevated temperature, in addition to cyclic mechanical loading. Oxygen and temperature heavily degrade the materials' properties. This degradation is known as aging and induces brittle, shrunken, and aggravated surfaces. The aging process, coupled with mechanical loading, intensifies crack propagation in elastomers and reduces their serviceability. Experimental testing of aging is, necessarily, a time-consuming process. Having a theoretical framework that can be used for simulations will tremendously speed up the development of new, exciting, and reliable materials with a broader range of applications. This work will elucidate how the mechanical response of elastomers changes over their lifetime under the coupled effects of mechanical loading and aging. This research will advance the scientific knowledge of degradation effects on durability of elastomers. The development cycle of the project consists of experimental work, followed by modeling, simulation, and back to experimental verification. This combined approach, which is an ideal illustration of the scientific method, will be used for outreach to K-12 and minority students through university programs. This research will also train a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in this interdisciplinary field, forming the next generation of scientists that the U.S. elastomer industry critically needs to compete globally. 

To characterize the evolution of the deformation response and failure mechanism of elastomers under thermo-chemo-mechanical aging processes, this project outlines a series of interconnected experimental, theoretical, and numerical studies of the chemical, morphological, and mechanical changes. In the first stage of work, the aggravation of macrostructural mechanical properties of elastomers will be experimentally linked to their morphological changes (such as cross-link breakage/formation, and transformation of linkages). The second stage of the project will develop a mathematically verifiable procedure for incorporating stored and dissipated energies - obtained in chemical experiments - into the thermodynamic formalism. In the third stage, the project seeks to understand the effects of heterogeneous aging degradation on the mechanical response of elastomers. Numerical simulations of the constitutive equations will be used to verify the model against further experimental studies. The to-be-obtained knowledge and to-be-developed theoretical framework will lead to highly coupled physics-based models which map the elastomers' macrostructural behavior and failure mechanisms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Elastomers and polymers serve a wide range of engineering applications, from tire rubber and sealants to plastic water bottles. In these applications, polymers are often exposed to oxygen, UV irradiation, elevated temperatures, and cyclic mechanical loading. Such environmental conditions significantly degrade the materials' properties, a process known as aging. Aging leads to shrunken and deteriorated surfaces as well as brittle fracture. When combined with mechanical loading, the aging process accelerates crack propagation in polymers and reduces their service life.

 

In this project, we developed an experimental-theoretical framework to create numerical models capable of simulating and predicting the response of polymers degraded under environmental conditions. We demonstrated that the macromolecular changes in polymer networks can be quantitatively linked to their mechanical responses. Consequently, we elucidated how the mechanical behavior of polymer samples evolves over their lifetime under the combined effects of mechanical loading and aging.

 

We established physics- and chemistry-based constitutive frameworks to predict the stress and brittle failure responses of polymers subjected to thermochemical and photo-oxidative aging, within the context of a phase-field approach. These constitutive models were numerically implemented in a finite element framework. The constitutive models were validated against experimental results for both thermochemical and photo-oxidative aging. The comparisons confirmed that the proposed constitutive models accurately predict the stress-strain and failure responses of aged elastomers and polymers. Additional numerical examples were provided to illustrate the effects of evolving material properties on the response of specimens with pre-existing cracks. Moreover, we investigated the length scale parameter within the phase field approach and showed that this parameter is also a material property and can be obtained as a function of polymer network. 

 

Moreover, as current phase-field algorithms face elevated computational costs due to the so-called staggered solution scheme, we conducted a quantitative analysis to address this issue. For the first time, we presented a detailed comparison of two common solution strategies for the coupled large-deformation solid mechanics-phase-field problem: the quasi-Newton-based Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) algorithm and the full-Newton-based alternating minimization (AM/staggered) algorithm.

 

Our analysis demonstrated that the BFGS algorithm is a more efficient and advantageous alternative to the traditional AM/staggered approach for solving coupled large-deformation solid mechanics-phase-field problems. The results highlighted the potential of the quasi-Newton BFGS algorithm to significantly reduce the computational cost of predicting crack propagation in polymers, while maintaining the accuracy and robustness of the phase-field method.

 

This research advanced scientific understanding of the degradation effects on the durability of elastomers and polymers. The project followed a development cycle consisting of experimental work, modeling, simulation, and experimental verification, creating a continuous feedback loop. This integrated approach, which exemplifies the scientific method, was also utilized for outreach to K-12 and minority students through university programs. Furthermore, the research trained a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in this interdisciplinary field, preparing the next generation of scientists that the U.S. polymer industry critically needs to remain competitive globally.

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2024
Modified by: Maryam Shakiba

por.por_txt_cntn:
Elastomers and polymers serve a wide range of engineering applications, from tire rubber and sealants to plastic water bottles. In these applications, polymers are often exposed to oxygen, UV irradiation, elevated temperatures, and cyclic mechanical loading. Such environmental conditions significantly degrade the materials' properties, a process known as aging. Aging leads to shrunken and deteriorated surfaces as well as brittle fracture. When combined with mechanical loading, the aging process accelerates crack propagation in polymers and reduces their service life.





In this project, we developed an experimental-theoretical framework to create numerical models capable of simulating and predicting the response of polymers degraded under environmental conditions. We demonstrated that the macromolecular changes in polymer networks can be quantitatively linked to their mechanical responses. Consequently, we elucidated how the mechanical behavior of polymer samples evolves over their lifetime under the combined effects of mechanical loading and aging.





We established physics- and chemistry-based constitutive frameworks to predict the stress and brittle failure responses of polymers subjected to thermochemical and photo-oxidative aging, within the context of a phase-field approach. These constitutive models were numerically implemented in a finite element framework. The constitutive models were validated against experimental results for both thermochemical and photo-oxidative aging. Additional numerical examples were provided to illustrate the effects of evolving material properties on the response of specimens with pre-existing cracks. Moreover, as current phase-field algorithms face elevated computational costs due to the so-called staggered solution scheme, we conducted a quantitative analysis to address this issue. For the first time, we presented a detailed comparison of two common solution strategies for the coupled large-deformation solid mechanics-phase-field problem: the quasi-Newton-based BroydenFletcherGoldfarbShanno (BFGS) algorithm and the full-Newton-based alternating minimization (AM/staggered) algorithm.





Our analysis demonstrated that the BFGS algorithm is a more efficient and advantageous alternative to the traditional AM/staggered approach for solving coupled large-deformation solid mechanics-phase-field problems. The results highlighted the potential of the quasi-Newton BFGS algorithm to significantly reduce the computational cost of predicting crack propagation in polymers, while maintaining the accuracy and robustness of the phase-field method.





This research advanced scientific understanding of the degradation effects on the durability of elastomers and polymers. The project followed a development cycle consisting of experimental work, modeling, simulation, and experimental verification, creating a continuous feedback loop. This integrated approach, which exemplifies the scientific method, was also utilized for outreach to K-12 and minority students through university programs. Furthermore, the research trained a diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students in this interdisciplinary field, preparing the next generation of scientists that the U.S. polymer industry critically needs to remain competitive globally.
